grownfools Even the postman knows whats in those packages tasting.  Bottle shared by grownfool.  Orange-red, whitish cover.  Dry funky, acidic aroma.  Taste is sweeter, light acidic, candy.

375 mL bottle courtesy of Papsoe. Shared at the 11th Richmond Ratebeer Gathering, 4/17/10. Pours a slightly hazy brown color with a thin head. Decent head retention and lacing. Aroma of caramel, earthy notes, some breadiness and a very, very mild tartness in the finish. The taste is caramel, some plum, earthy notes and a mild funk. Medium bodied. Decent beer. MUCH better than the first faro I tried.

I actually liked this more than I expected. It smells like a regular geuze, with notes of stone, lemon and vinegar. Flavor is also typical geuze - citric acid, stone and vinegar, but if you concentrate real hard, you can get some sweetness. . Actually enjoyed this.

Bottle 37,5 cl from www.erzbierschop.ch. Red beer crimson saturated in plentiful foam off-white hanging on laces on the glass. Tart and fruity flavors, cider, lactic and medicinal keys. The taste is sour but moderated by sugar, fruity, touch of woody, apple, bitter almond, rancid and light notes. It spreads out on acidity, vinous, coated with toffy fading in finale.

Bottled sample consumed at Cambrinus. Pale amber in colour with moderate carbonation. Restrained aromas of funk, wood, and lemon. Theres a bit of sugar sweetness upfront in the mouth, but it fades quickly into more typical lemon, funk, wood, and leather territory. Light bodied. I quite enjoyed this one.

My first Faro, making it only 3 unrated RB beer styles.  Orange copper pour with big fat bubbles.  Head disappears and leaves a mass of frogs eggs.  Nose is cinammon spice and light sour.  Taste is lightly and brightly tart/sour.  Moves to flat bitter aspirin and yeasty sharpness thing.  Enjoyable beer.

Bottle shared by lagunitasfan.  Damp smelling but somewhat metallic..tame mildew..deep amber body with very impressive, silky sheet of tan suds atop.  Flavors combine sweetness and sourness delicately,  but seemlessly into a relaxing, not overly complex, yet relaxing concotion.  Theres a subtle white grapey undertone and a sweaty, wet sock like thing going on that makes it not overly boring.  Not too shabby.
37,5 cl bottle. Red/Amber body with off-white head. Flavour is sour, sweet, caramel and fruit.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2016 Sampled at the Richmond Eleventh.  THANK YOU DKACHUR!!!!!! A long sought after style is finally under my belt.  Pours a hazy dark amber with good white head.   Kinda mild funky nose with a hint of smokiness.  The flavor is muted, like old dry lambic.  Not very acidic.  Not biting, Not offensive, but not all that great.  Very glad to have finally tried this style, but not all that impressed.  

Tried it again sic years later in Belgium.  Opinion hasnt changed.

(Sample Date: 4/17/2010   Source:Dkachur)   Sweet caramelized sugars and moderate fruitiness in aroma. Mostly clear copper golden with hefty carbonation and little head. Sweet and sour with caramelized sugar and malts. Finish is medium sweet with a certain earthiness. Interesting.

Medium amber, courtesy of dkachur.  Always special to be able to try a faro.  Aroma is muted horeseblanket.  Flavor matches - muted horseblanket, slight cheese, plenty of funk.  Sweet and sour finish.  Nice, although the sugar note is always a bit jarring in a faro.  Almost like saccharin added.

Draught at Het Warm Water, Brussels. Dark brown with no head. Ripe dark fruit sweetness, caramel and very woody in aroma and taste. Sweet finish. Very drinkable but not sure if this would keep my interest for long.
Pours a amber with a small off-white head. The aroma is sweet sour, fruity and light acid. The taste is very sweet, light sour fruity and acid.

Bottle. Thanks Boutip (phil)! Dark copper pour with thin white veil. Funky, barnyard aroma, some orange peel and cherries. Taste is very sweet, somewhat grassy with a lot of fruits too. Strange "heavy" lambic.

Tasting at DØE-meeting, Aarhus Syd, DK.
Bottled, 170310.
Amber with small head. Aroma of acid and fruit. Flavor is cane sugar with the sour backbone. Why artiifical additives?

Corked 375ml bottle from Dranken Geers. Pours deep copper with a creamy white collar. Caramelised boiled sweet and rust aroma like a crappy pasteurised bitter; an underlying crumb of dank vinegared wood and little streaks of green apple acidity disclosing the lambic content. Damp and uninteresting like watered-down Rodenbach; faint mildew, muscovado and malt loaf but not enough to prevent it ending up tasting like a Flemish sour shandy made with low cal lemonade.

Bottle @ ZBF 2010. A clear dark golden colored beer, with a thick white head. The aroma of sweet with notes of wood. The atste is a little sour woody. Notes of sherry and sweet. The aftertaste is mostly sweet with a little bitter.

Drain pour. First off, it is technically impossible to bottle true Faro. It will detonate in the bottle. Anyway, it pours a clear light amber with a tiny tan head. Malty aroma with closet and barnhouse floor. Taste is really odd with sickly sweetness, stale grains, chemicals. Yuck.

Pours a pale yellow with a champagnish foam.
The aroma has raspberry that is very distinct, also has barnyard, and the sourness of the beer is also notable in the nose.
The taste is sour, but not in a bad way. It also has these slight raspberry notes.

Bouteille verte de 375 ml, avec bouchon de lière, obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur de fruité légèrement sûrette. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée voilée. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de fruité sucré mais légèrement acide. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture vineuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de raisins verts en arrière goût. (Rating #2923)
Tasting at ZBF. Clear amber color with a small head. Aroma is sour with some sweetness. Taste is a good balance between sour and sweet. Nice brew.
This is the faro that made me give the style another chance.  Intriguing blend of sweet and funky; not a super syrupy sweet flavor, but balanced perfectly with the acidity.
Bottle @ ZBF 2010. Pours a straw colored beer, nearly no head. Very drinkable, light bodied, soft carbonation. Aftertaste is some caramel syrup, but subtle.
Pours copper with a large beige head. Aroma is acidic, light fruity and horseblanket. Flavour is sweet at first, citrus and barnyard. Grapefruit in the aftertaste.

Bottle from a trade with Boutip. Pours clear copper color with beige head.  Aroma is sweet with some barnyard funk. Flavor is mildly tart and not as sweet as I was expecting. Not much lingering flavors. Thin body with moderate carbonation. Thanks Phil.
Bottle from nbutler, thanks! Pours an amberish color.  Aroma is cherry sucrets.  Flavor is cherry sucrets:)
Bottle courtesy of Canadian Santa -- thanks!  Pours amber in color with a dusty off-white head.   Smells and tastes of cane sugar along with mild notes of straw and underripe fruit.  Meh.

(Bottle, date stamp on cork was 05/07, at Pikkulintu) Poured amber and lightly hazy with medium sized, white and long lasting head. Aroma contained sourness and candy sugar. Palate was medium bodied and dry with medium carbonation. Flavours were malts, sweetness, sourness and mild bitterness. Aftertaste was sweet and sour. The beer tasted a bit too old, unfortunately.

Reddish amber color with a surprisingly big head with just the slightest pinkish hue. Good retention as well and nice lacings.

A rather mild smell, restrained and easygoing for a lambic. You can tell that the vinegar and funky notes ad subdued by the sweetening. Still some vinegar, apples, lemon, grass and hay. Gentle funkiness as well. Some tart fruity aromas.

The taste is also restrained and gentle. It lacks a little complexity and perhaps some balance but its still tasty. Nice fruity notes of apples and some cherries. Lemons. Mild tartness balanced by a well integrated sweetness. Luckily, the sweetness doesnt have that candy-like feel to it that some overly sweetened lambics have. Restrained notes of wet hay, barnyard and earthy yeast. The finish is dry with a refreshing tartness, citric notes and a gentle grassy bitterness. Some slightly too prominent mineral notes in the finish as well.

Moderate to light body. The carbonation seems a little off, its like the bubbles are too big or something.

A very easy to drink lambic with mellow flavors and a restrained tartness due to the sweetening. Refreshing. All in all, not a bad beer.

Serving type: bottle

(Copy of old Beer Advocate review)
Bottle, 37,5cl. Pours a clear amber beer with a big offwhite head. The aroma is sweet with acidity. The flavor is sweet, fruit and acidity. The palate is dry. Overall an average beer.

37,5cl bottle, 07/08 printed on the cork. Dark amber, firm light beige head, tight lace. Beautiful buttery nutty aroma, rotten fruits, sweetness, earthy liquorice, faint funkiness and farm house. Later on I got some Yogi tea and rye porridge. Flavor holds woody sourness, little old fruits, funk and nuttiness. Sugar cuts the tartness down but doesnt really taste. Long earthy and woody finish. Medium bodied, strongly carbonated fizzy but quenching palate. The two bottles I had were similarly magical, subtle but so rich.

A nose of vanilla, vinegar, oak, and lemon detergent for dish washing. Taste is of oak, apples, metal and funk. Its sweet and a little bit sour. Finish is dry. Hmmm... I dont know what to make of this.
Aroma is a bit weak but of funk, citrus and vanilla. Appearance is gold/amber with big white head. Flavor is sweet with hint of funk, citrus and soap. Overall not an amazing beer.
Courtesy Glouglouburp. Ugly brown. Off white head. Funk, earth, stale crackers/cookies, petting zoo, iced tea. Medium body, moderate/light carbonation. Need to try more of this style.

375ml bottle, cork dated Feb 2009.  Pours a clear reddish amber hue with a small head of beige foam.  A soapy wash mostly rejoins the body, scant dots of wet lacing remaining behind.  The aroma shows notes of musty, earthy, fermenting fig and other dark fruits, followed up by caramelized sugar sweetness and mildly funky, oaky tartness.  There is a very faint hint of aged floral hops on the nose.  Flavors are sweet-tart, caramelized fig and fruit soured by notes of apple cider and old, wet wood.  Medium-light bodied, the palate sports a moderately fizzy carbonation.  Overall, its decent, but like most faros, a little too sweet for my lambic tastes.
Brown and a bit hazy. Has an off-white head. Aroma of light burnt sugar, wood. Flavor starts moderate sweet, moderate acidic and finish lightly bitter. Dry texture. Lively carbonation.
Bottle: Poured a murky brown with no head. Aroma is musty fruit and sugar. Taste is a mix to the tongue of sugar yet still has a barnyard funk to it.
Dark orange with a frothy head. Casky aroma, taste is bitter-sour and lasts very long.
Amber with a small white head. Aroma of grapefruit and leather. Flavour of mold, cellar and slightly tart.

Bottle courtesy of eclectic.  Deep amber with a thin white head.  The aroma is lightly sweet with a bit of sweet caramel and white sugar.  There is a soft sweet chewiness.  Fresh and lightly herbal.  A lingering apple sweetness on the back.  Just a kiss of funkiness.

@Pauls Girardin unblendeds chugging-courtesy of eclectic thanks Kevin-37.5cl bottlepours a very thin off white head and copper color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-brown sugar, dark fruit-prune/raisin.  Taste is sweet medium malt-sugar, medium fruit, some earthy.  Soft effervescence.
bottle, light beige colour, small but stable beige head, sour and sweet smell, also like the taste. But surprisingly not too sweet for a faro! Subtile and refreshing beer.

Bottle, 37,5 cl. A light-brown bear with a lacing medium beige head. The aroma is sour (lambic) and light sweet (sugar candy), also light fruity. The taste is a perfect combination of lambic, which gives this faro a sour touch and the sugar candy, preserving the agreeable sweet taste. Not too sweet at all, an ideal beautfil combination. Also some fruity touches in the end.
Bottle. Clear amber body with a medium off white head. Malty aroma with some ripe fruit and raisins. Light spicy flavour with some fruit and sweet malt. Light sour touch. Medium bodied.
This non-opaque brown beer poured with no head at all and a brown sugar aroma. It starts real sweet with a sour dry finish.

Rather dark, malt vinegar look to it. Sweet, dusty aroma, with honey, dried fruit, citrus and lactic acid. Ok sweet/sour flavor balance, with caramel and yogurt. Nice bitter, dry, finish, but too sweet overall.

Bottle with courtesy of plovmand. 
It pours an amber colour with a off white head. 
Aroma is sweet with notes of rock candy, raisin, grape, wood and fruit. 
Flavour is a little watery with notes of malt, raisins, rock candy, wood and hay. 
Although its not as sweet as many other faros its still not really my thing.

Had a few times- latest shared by Eclectic.  This time eclectics bottle seemed a bit more clean than previous tastings where I have noticed more dirtiness, garbage, dms and tons of diacetyl on occasion.  Aroma here is cleaned up- sweet still, brown sugar, candi sugar, caramel sweetness, honey light apple and acetaldehyde and light funk.  Flavor is sweet, but not quite too sweet even for the style, light funk, some acids in the background, honey, green apple, light dms, caramel, and brown sugar- with a fake syrupy sweetness- slightly slick finish.  I dont like Faro, but this wasnt that bad for a bottled version.

Bottle. Pours deep chestnut coloured with a creamy off white head. Musty aroma with notes of spices, sour fruit, wood and sugar. Spicy balsamic flavour with notes of wood and sour fruit. The finish is a little thin and watery. Overall a decent faro - not as sweet as a feared.

On tap at In de Wildeman as Platte Faro. Clear dark amber colour with a soapy white disappearing head. Aroma of blue cheese and dust. Flavour is blue cheese, some malts, acid, some brown sugar. No carbonation. Another visitor said it tasted like old monks sweat. I have to agree. Its just god-awful.

Bottle @ WSF. Dark coppery amber with lasting beige head. Aroma is slightly oxidized, earthy, fuzzy, musty, moldy, and woody. the palate is gentle but with pretty high carbonation. Odd flavors include lots of wood, some apple core, and earth. Not very sweet, and has lots of funk. One of the least sweet, least faro-like faros I have encountered.
Bottle at the Rake:  Nice hints of sourness but nothing more. Surprisingly malty. Weird fruits. Not as refined as I would like. A good introduction to lambics?

Source:  Bottle purchased at the Rake in London. Glass: Poured into a Rodenbach stem glass. Appearance: Dark amber with a one finger beige head.  Aroma:  Sweet malt, brown sugar and molasses.   Flavor: Hint of vinegar with sweet malt and brown sugar. Palate:  Medium/light body with solid carbonation.Overall:  Another tick...not a bad beer either.
Tap @ Bier Circus.  Pours tea-brown and still.  Aroma of burnt sugar.  Taste is odd with the sugar and sourness.  A good deal of acetone in there.  Finishes yeasty.  Not into this at all.

Bottle. Pours clear amber, heavy carbonation. White head that becomes thin after a while but still is quite long-lasting. Somewhat acidy aroma of good lambiek with some caramel and some coffee in the background. First taste bitter-sour with brown sugar. For a faro this one has a very nice palate:some sour from the lambiek,some sweet sugar, but also some bitterness in the aftertaste. Very nice faro!

clear amber, large thick smoth offwhite head.
dry aroma of brett, stable, fruits, balanced, and hinting at a good sour experience.
flavor is bitter, brett, berries in the background, sweetness,  not much sourness, still comes off as a nice bittersweet bretty slightly sour thing.

Its a beautiful brown-red/copper color and the head is small. The aroma has notes of sweetness, sourness, peal of citrus fruits and some cane sugar. The flavour has sweetness and sourness with notes of peal of grapefruit and oranges, a tart grapefruit that develops and some sour berries also are found. Now, Im not a Faro specialist in any way, but I prefer the Lindemans... 2334 (had forgotten to ad this rating 2 years old)

Bottle shared at Andys tasting.  Think this one may have been from Andy, not sure though.  My first Faro.  Pours a hazy light brown with a thin white head.  Aromas are coffee, toffee, and vanilla.  Sweet, with a touch of brown sugar.  Light finish with a touch of bitterness.  Not even close to what I was expecting, but this was still fairly tasty.

Bottle: Amber pour with a dense tan head. Has a sweet & tart aroma of caramelized sugar, as well as Swiss cheese and moldy oxidized notes. Creamy & velvety palate. Has a smooth sugary sweetness and a papery molded note. Some cheese rind funk as well. The sugar works well in this example.
Bottle. Copper colour with nearly no off-white head. Aroma is sour, sugar. Flavour is dry, sugar, sour, sweet, cork, yeast. Nice beer.

Bottle 35 cl. My first Faro to rate. Pours a rather clear kobber with an off-white head. The nose is a little metallic with some sour apples and a little vanilla. All together the aroma is rather low key. The taste is sweet with buttery undertones and finish - and thus a fat palate. There is also some dried prunes and  plums, and finaly brown sugar. ... Makes you burb..cool

bottle. The aroma is sour, reminds me a little bit of cider vinegar. The head is relatively large, white and creamy, the duration is long. The body is orange and cloudy. The first taste started sour, then it gets a little bit sweeter, the duration is medium. The body is light, very dry and light watery with lively carbonation. A good beer.

Bottle at home. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head. Smells a bit of athletes feet. Tart with Fruity aromas. Quite tart for a faro. Quite citric. Tiny hints of metals and bog myrtle. Medium body. High carbonation. Tart and citric finish with a tiny hint of diacetyl.

Dark brown pour with a small quickly receding head. Fresh funky aroma. Taste is very funky, lots of horseblanket, moderately sour, dry. Unlike the few other faros I have tried this one has only very little sweetness. For some reason this didnt really meet my expectations, its too sweet for a Gueuze but not sweet enough for a Faro (or at least what my idea of Faro is).

Thanks OldStyleCubFan for sharing. Pours a bubbly ruby colored brew with a two finger creamy offwhite head. The nose was sweet, had a tart vinous character, raisiny, light earthy character. The flavor is tart and vinous, has a candy like sweetness that coexists with the tart and acidic qualities of the base lambic.

Sampled at the Carolina Crew tasting thanks to OldStyleCubFan - thanks, Todd! It pours a fine amber/garnet color with fine carbonation. The nose is initially deep and floral, but deepens with a soft, mead-like quality. While there are dry, tart undertones to the taste, the muscat and honey notes come through to make this a delicious blend, with a nicely bitter finish. Really fine, a happy introduction to the style.

Thanks to Todd for sharing with the Carolina Crew.  Deep mahogany pour with small bubbly white head.  Sour lambic nose but backed up by a caramel sweetness. Some leather and earthy sweet vegetal notes.  Easy to drink and quite sessionable. Slightly overcarbonated palate, I thought.

Pours deep copper with small light brown head. Very pleasant acidic aroma. Excellent tartness with a sweeter touch than other lambics. Nasty aftertaste from the artificial sweetener costs a few marks.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2010 bottle by way of glouglouburp.1/20/2008

rich copper colored pour with a short lived vigorous white head. seems pretty dark, no?

it smells sweet and grainy yet still tart and dusty... aromas include caramel, cement, leather and red apple cider with warming spices.

same thing goes for the flavor.... it*s a mix of sweet and sour i*ve not yet sampled. flavors of sweet bruised red apples, caramel, dust, copper/minerals and yeast with a mild soft tartness. the finish is dry and grainy with some cinnamon creeping in as it warms. medium to rich bodied. it*s rather thick and oily but parching and dry at the same time.

neato...
8/4.5/7.5/4/16/4.0

bottle 1/2/2010 from nbutler11

it smells incredibly slate-y/mineraly with a ton of sweet caramel grain.

the flavor is full of apple, raisin and fruity sweetness with funky dusty yeast lingering in the background.

again, full bodied but still dry... 8/4/8/4/16/4.0
Sample courtesy of hellbilly. Aroma reminded me of pitching silage from the silo as a kid. Bronse body with off white head. Good mix of sout, tart and fruits like lambic style. Thanks Josh

Bottle shared by hellbilly.  Deep amber-red pour with a foamy light head.  Sweet aroma of caramel malt, apples, yeast and lemons.  Flavor starts sweet and malty, but there is some sourness lurking in the back.  Finish is fruity and somewhat spicy.  It sort of goes in every possible direction, but very nice overall.  Thanks for my first Faro Josh!

Courtesy of hellbilly

Pours a nice reddish brown with a off white head. Aroma is sweet malt grains caramel and a cidery acidity. Flavor is acitdic sour vinegar caramel malt grains and belgian yeasts. Interesting beer its like a sweet sour. Thanks for the taste Josh

On draught at Bier Circus.  I don’t like sweet beers, so I didn’t expect much from this one, but the owner Patrick talked me into it.  Glad he did.  Wonderful balance of sweet/sour, with great complexity.  Tops the Cantillon Faro, which I had the night before.  An incredible experience.
Thanks to Todd fro sharing. Dark amber pour with thin fizzy head. Sweet acidic aroma. Caramel, and dark fruit flavor. Sweet and tart

375ml I got via trade, I can’t recall from who.  Pours dark red with a tan ring.  Nose is sweet and tart and sugary.  Taste is sweet, tart and slightly sugary.  Its interesting and a strange beer, but I like it.

375ml bottle. Amber body with almost no head. Acidic aroma with caramel and dry fruit. Flavor is sweet and sour with a hit of caramel and dry fruit. The Brettomyces is lurking somewhere in the background. Quite nice.
Hazy reddish amber colour. Some hints of toffee in the nose. Also some sweetness and sourness too. Not very special. Tasted at Pikkulintu.

Bottle, from the BSF at the 2008 GBBF. Russet brown, fine off-white cap. Late autumn apple-sweet aroma, leaf piles, dusty leather chair. A bit of copper, clean wool socks, slightly off butter. More apple-butter flavor, gently sour and woody. Initially too sweet for my taste, but a few sips it seems to find its feet, and a fine cinnamon dryness outlines the edges nicely.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2008 Bottle at Delirium Cafe, Gothenburg. A slightly hazy copper colored beer with a fingerthick off-white head. Lovely sourish, funky and mellow nose with some sugar. Nice, sugar-sweet, fruity and lemoney flavor. Quite carbonated, sweetish yet astringent mouthfeel, and a long, sweet finish with citrus flavors. Definiately a nice one. Rating: 7-4-6-3-14-3.4. (080710)Bottle, 37.5cl corked. Pours an almost clear, orange-golden body under a minimal off-white head. Sour, yet sugary aroma with cellar and some cork. Quite sugary flavor with some sourness, cellar and cork. Flat and dry, and finishing with sourness, sweetness and an earthy flavor. It seems the cork have left some flavor and aroma in the beer, much more than I have noticed earlier, but still it is a nice and easy to drink beer. (080926)
38cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, not complex brew, yet balanced, clear, small head, nothing special

Bottle at dilirium Gøteborg: Red hazy colour, with a nice head. Aroma of sournes,fruity,flowery. Flavor was a clean sournes profile, with a nice smouth mouth feeling. Werry complex  and nice beer. Long fruity finish. Nice

37,5cl @ Olbutikken, Copenhagen. Pours cloudy amber/orange with a creamy lasting head. Aroma is mouldy, sweet, cellar, vinegar & dusty. Medium body & carbonation. Some apple & fruity notes. Delicious & drinkable Faro.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2008 Orange brown with a funky sour nose and a huge head. The flavours are weird and in strange directions, at one point I even tasted pizza and tomato juice..  The big picture is sugarish sourness though with a nice wooden touch. But why on earth are there additives in my lambic?!! Werent the lambics supposed to be original, natural examples of Belgian brewing tradition?

Bottle at The Rake, with renffisch, duff and harrisoni, 17th May 2008. Slightly hazy amber/orange with a persistent white head. Strong aroma of gooseberries, spices and sour apples. The apple flavour combines wonderfully with demerra sugar flavours, ably abetted by a lively palate that tickles the  tongue with bubbles. Smooth and flavoursome, this is a very good Faro.

Aroma:  spicy, black pepper, some mustiness, minerals, brown sugar

Appearance:  golden brown, white head, lacing

Flavor:  bran, carmel, American amber-aleness, some minerals/earthiness, brown sugar, black pepper, spices

Palate:  "amber ale-ness" and black pepper aftertaste
Im a huge fan of spontanious fermentation, but this faro doesnt appeal to me very much. Too sweet and though its rather complex it doesnt seem to exploit the potential.

Pours a clear reddish brown color with a medium, diminishing offwhite head.  The aroma has a nice match of sugary sweetness and lambic funk and sourness. The flavor has a nice balance between the sugary sweetness and the Girardin lambic. The body is light with an oily texture and gentle carbonation. With 3 Fonteinen Faro, this is the best faro Ive sampled so far, but then again, why bother drinking faro when you have a ton of Girardin Black Label at home?

Dark red in color. Thanx to oh6gdx. Medium sized reddish head, lazings. The aroma is sweet and barnyard like. The flavor is sweet and almost gueze like in the shape of a lambic!?!?  Nice, sweet and sour in one package, compelling. Sweet, yepp, nice

bottle at the rake, thanks to harrisoni. dark mahogany colour, good creamy head. nose of sour whey, and a bit of glucose. very balanced faro, not too sweet, but still very heavy on the glucose. quite a lot of bread with a good hint of pepper. grand faro, i thought.
Botella. Hazy deep red colour. Fruity cherry sourish aroma. Good mouthfeel. The flavour has a good frutiness with cherries, yeast, toasty malt and a nice sourness. Nice dry sour fruity finish.

My first faro, thanks probtsk.  Pours like a naturally carbonated aged beer, similar to geuze but for the pinking tinge.  White head. Cherry in the aroma, and significantly in the taste. Medium and smooth mouthfeel.  Easy drinking with a meal. On the sweet side, without foodi t would be too much.

375ml bottle.  Mild murkiness to the pour (brown color) with a large tan head.  Sweet brown sugar, caramel and honey nose - dusty, dry minerals as well (and some yeast) when warmer.  Toasted grains and bread and some sweet brown sugar covered fruit tastes, a little bit of peppery yeast as well (and rye bread).  There’s certainly a lot going on, but of course with faro it’s missing the acidity and it’s too sweet.  Comes across as bran, toast, toffee and brown sugar, some light tartness and acidity when warmer, and it leaves the palate somewhat dry and puckery, but the sourness is very light and mostly hidden and overwhelmed by the brown sugar and caramel sweetness.

Tap at Het Warm Water. Clear amber color with no head. Slightly lactic aroma. Thinnish body with hardly any carbonation. Slightly acidic flavor - rather citric. Mild funk. A bit fruity. Fairly dry finish. Rather refreshing. I think like faroes.

[1155-20080301] Bottle. Aroma of sweet mushroom sauce and chicken. Clear, dark brown amber body with a quick bubbly light brown head. Bit of alcohol but flavour is mostly sweet malt and mushrooms and a sour finish. Medium body is sour. Quite good, drinkable, repeatable.
(ZBF 2008; Sint Niklaas, BE)

Bottled. Beer Circus, Brussels. 
Ultra clear copper colour. No head. Raisiny nose with no sweetness detected. Raisin backbone in flavour, with slight sweetness and bit woody. Nice, balanced beer.
Draught at Deliruim. Clear amber colour with a small white head. Initial sour notes with a semi sweet finish. Nice faro.
UPDATED: APR 18, 2008 bottle at rake. Nose of apple and yeast.  Apple notes. Slighty carbonated, malty. A touch sour. Lacks the complexities of other Lambics. Not bad.
on tap at delirium.  one of my first faros so not sure how to rate, but thoroughly enjoyable.  Slightly sour finish to match the aroma.  Ill rerate after Ive sampeled a few more.
Thx for another great tasting, Kim (Beljohansen).Clear amber, lasting head, notes of malt, candy and toffee, sweet.

(3/2/08) Bottle sample at Zythos Bier Festival 2008 in Sint Niklaas. Amber color with an off-white head. A quite weak aroma for a Lambic with some wood and sugar. Sweet flavor with some light sour notes and some light wood and fruits. Medium-bodied. OK.
Thanks to Jk for sharing this rare treat.  A sour nose with sweet caramel notes.  Malty flavor with caramel  and apples.  Slightly funky with a sour finish.

Bottle. Pours a copper colour with a big off-white head. Nose is malty gueuze sparkle, some alcohol and warm malts at the end of the sniff. Mouth is sparkly coating sweet lemon icing, apples and some champagne, but just as its getting good, it gets sweet. A cocktease of a beer. Palate is sweet but tangy, good, but i wish it could be allowed to continue to a sour end...

Heavy malty and white wine aroma. Average, frothy, off-white initial apperance. Fair lacing. Mostly diminishing longevity. Clear red brown body. Heavy bitter flavor and a long finish duration. Medium palate, watery texture and lively carbonation.
Bottle at ZBF 2008. Clear dark red/brown - white head. Aroma: wet dog, light sourness, light malty. Taste: Mushrooms, champion, brown sugar, light light cherries, high sweetness. Not very pleasant.
Deep amber with tiny head. Sweet malty aroma with light sour brett notes. Same goes for the somewhat sweet flavor. I will never learn to appreciate sweetened lambic...
Bottle. Muddy amber colour with small white fully diminishing head. Vinegar aroma. Sweet acetic flavor.

Bottle. Creamy off-white good mostly lasting head. Amber colour. Powerfull nice complex aroma. Moderate sweet and acetic flavor. Well-balanced. Average finish. Oily palate. Pleasent to drink also for people who normally dislike lambics.

2008-03-01. Mahogany-chestnut brown body with a waifish beige head. Modest aroma, muted sournes over barely there fruit. Simple sweetness in the flavour, apple juice like fruitiness. Extremely muted notes of hor or barnyard in the background if you look for them. (6+) Average palate. Pleasantly drinkable - I can see having this with a meal - but not complex or assertive enough to score more highly. Bottle at Zythos Festival, St. Niklaas

Draught at Beer Circus, Brussels.
Brown with a bubbly, small head.
Sourish aroma; vinegar.
Almost flat.
Kinda sweet but still with fine soruish notes.
Some light vinous touch with fruitiness; raisins.
Bottle.  Sweet sugar and sour musty malt aroma.  Dark amber with large head.  Creamy, slightly sweet malt flavor initially folowed by musty barnyard flavor.  Not overly sweet.

From tap/cask at Bier Circus according to the chalkboard - I did see a 10 L box of this while easting and the beer was served living room temp. hot. Pours cola brown, clear, has a little bobbly white head. Light caramel aroma, light sweet note, but mainly a mild butterish note. Sweet caramel flavour wit a light butterish flavour and somewhat butterish mouthfeel. Light caramel lingering finish, shows a mild acidic bite aswell. Just plain boring cane sugarish and caramel brew.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2013 Draught at the Beer Circus, Brussel, Belgium. Clear orange brown, like tea, with a few bubbles. Cidery aroma with some woody notes, brown sugar and raisins. Light in body and soft, good balance with a light sweetness followed by a dry and bitter finish. My first sample of this style, and it was not very exciting.
assaggiato alla spina color ambrato carico sentori dolciastri di caramello zucchero candito finale legermente acidulo
Thanks to Fordest for sharing.  Pours amber with a minimal white head.  Aroma of burnt candied sugar, however the burnt sugar aroma is quick to dissipate.  Flavors were sweet and tart.

Tasted 2008-02-28. Bottle of unknown date. Pours clear, amber with off-white head. Aroma: Canned peaches, brown sugar, a little citrus. Flavours: A little bitter/sweet, some tartness, brown sugar, peaches. Semi dry body. OK, but I find it a little boring.
My first Faro. By far my favorite. Nice sour, tart, burnt sugar flavors. Very much appreciated that this was shared. Not to many in this style floating around.

375 ml bottle thanks to Papsoe.  Very bubbly amber pour with nice white head.  Aromas were burnt, carmalized sugar and a plum like tartness in the background.  Flavors were sweet up front with only a little of that roasted caramel flavor.  Tartness took over in the middle, with a nice sweet finish. I like this style.  Now off to Belgium to have it on tap like it should be... right?... Someday...

from belgianshop.com - clear reddish-bordeaux colour under a fine and stable beige foam; robust aroma of cheese, rhubarb and vinegar; light to medium-bodied, effervescent, sweet and moderately acidic; the finish fails a bit short leaving some notes of raisins and apple

My friend Artem dragged this back from Belgium for me. It pours a dark, hazy amber color and has a small sticky head.  Aroma is root cane sugar sweetness and light citric molasses, which represents the lambic portion of the beer.  Taste is a lot less sweet and a lot of "simple" lambic that is lightly wild and citrus. Faint acidity, otherwise a light medium body.  Very enjoyable for a Faro. 375mL bottle, elongated thin Ommegang 10th Anniversary goblet glass.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Bottle (375ml) shared with HogTownHarry & garthicus -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a deep amber with a small diminishing off-white head. Aroma and flavour of caramel malt, wood, funky yeast and light spices. Some mild sourness in the taste. Average bodied. Very good stuff!

Shared with Harry and Blankboy - Nice amber colour; Tangy cider aroma with pepper too. Acidic bitter flavour, not overpowering but certainly not offensive. Almost like a cider-beer shandy. Very enjoyable

Bottle (375ml - green, corked & caged).  Shared with blankboy and garthicus, my bottle via trade with Viper666.  Clear  amber pour, large frothy off-white head.  Love that aroma - light acidic funky yeast and over top mildly sweet ripe apple.  The taste is similar, a little oxidized and sour, but still nice and fruity/yeasty.  Soft, watery body, fairly still, lightly acidic in the finish.

Great deep amber coloured body with a thinnish tan head. Aroma of sour grapes, apple cider vinegar, nuts, malt and a bit of hops - very complex for the style! Light to Medium-bodied; Acidic taste up front with a bunch of malt and hops, but fading to an appley taste with light grapes definitely noticeable. Aftertaste shows promise, with a fragrant grassy hop flavour mixed with vinegar and malt for a very complex taste. Overall, a nice complex lambic full of deep and robust flavours, but still leaving a little room for some sourness. I sampled this 375 mL split bottle purchased from Beer Mania in Bruxelles, Belgium on 30-December-2007.

Sunset orange colour with a white creamy head. There is no question, this is a sour brew but its more of a subtle hint of sour in the nose. Green apple and some other tart like fruit with a bit of yeast. Very carbonated with some funk with sour notes that are really nice, more subtle than some of the puckering sours but its still there. Thanks for letting us try the style, JK!

[Bottle, thanks JK] Pours orange with a light cream head. Aroma is slightly sour with apple and grape. Taste is similar but more tart. Medium mouthfeel. Long finish. Its a decent beer, but nothing too special.

On tap at Het Warm Water, Brussels March 2007. Dark amber with a moderate off-white head that left plenty of lacing. Tempting caramel aroma with some yeast and tart fruit. Flavour of demerara sugar, toffee and the barnyard with a decent dry finish. Very enjoyable.

Purchased at Bachus Cornelius, Brugge, March 2007.  I took the bottom of the bottle and this comes out opaque orange with a short, thick head.  Well carbonated from the corked and caged bottle.  No visible sediment.  Interesting and unusual aroma with yeast and ripe cheese.  Flavor is quite sour, more sour than some beers that call themselves a gueuze like Chapeau.   Some sugar in there, but this is a gueuze first.  A quality product like everything from Girardin.

Finally! I get to knock out my last remaining beer style that I have not tried. Lambic-Faro. Special thanks to JK for supplying this rarity. Pours a semi clear amber brew with a fizzy off-white head that has some good retention and lacing. Aroma of tart hard fruit, some caramel, a touch of green apple and yeast. Taste is tart, high carbonation, with flavors of green apple, barnyard hay and a touch of caramel. Finish is actually sweet than its initial tart flavor which make this a pretty decent lambic.

UPDATED: APR 12, 2008 Belgian Beer #200.  Who do I turn to when I need my rare Belgian beer fix?  JK, thats who!  Copper color with very little head.  Strong aroma of caramel, marshmallows and some sourness.  Much the same in the taste, but paired up with some of that barnyard funk.  Very sugary and sweet.  Wow, damn fine.

Pours amber with some white bubbles in the glass.  Smells funky with some barnyard hay like qualities.  Taste is of artificial sweetner and has some acidity but not very enjoyable.  The sugar really gets in the way in this one.

375ml bottle from Beer Mania in Brussels.  This beer is highly recommended.  This is the most well rounded Faro beer Ive ever had.  Dry, wheaty, and acidic like a traditional authentic gueuze, but the mild added sugar gives it a more rounded, orange, doughy flavor.  Not as sugary sweet as some other Faros out there.

Green bottle, 37,5 cl, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured October 26 2007; eye: amber, clear, light effervescence, nice almond head that remains, a bit of lacing; nose: sour green apple is quite present, light horse, sugar, apple vinegar, acidity; mouth: sugar, sour green apple, caramel, a bit thin, rather carbonated, light astringency, acidity is present throughout the sip but is quite diminished by the presence of the caramel, lightly sour, mildly sweet, medium to thin body, sitcky texture; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille verte, 37,5 cl, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savourée le 26 octobre 2007; il : ambrée, claire, légère effervescence, belle mousse amande qui se maintient, un peu de dentelle; nez : pomme verte aigre prononcée, léger cheval, sucre, vinaigre de cidre, acidité; bouche : sucre, pomme verte sûre, caramel, malt, cheval, vinaigre de cidre, finale en caramel, un peu mince, plutôt carbonatée, légère astringence, acidité présente tout au long de la gorgée mais très atténué par la présence du caramel, légèrement sûre, moyennement sucrée, corps moyen tirant vers le mince, texture collante; en résumé : correct

375ml bottle at Delirium Cafe. Huge head, dark brown pour. Burnt table sugar aroma -- scorched, even -- mushrooms and earth. Odd sweetness in the flavor, sugar is prevelent but mushrooms cover up most of the sweet. An odd drink, tastes kind of old & shot. Still looking for some real, fresh faro.
bottle at Ølbaren. ruddy brownish amber, no head, aroma of apple vinegar, stewed pear, initial flavour of flat coke, lemon iced tea then a hint of cherry sourness

My Bottom Line:
The fruitiness of tangy citrus and peach skins arbors the calculated wooden funk, as the brown sugar cornerstone progressively attenuates this lambic character until the tranquil finish is reached. This is a well-carved quencher which might help a few into the appreciation of lambic family products.

Further Personal Perceptions:
-A veil of foam tops the clear twilight orange.
-The tiny bubbles are fierce and expansive; this one gets better as it breathes.
-I would like that tartness to be prolonged somewhat, but then again that might make this stray from the style too much.
-There is enough funk throughout to recognize the lambic within.

Bottle.

Ill quote Devons name for the tasting as "Drewbeerme is back and is a badass for sharing so many awesome Belgium beers" tasting with xnoxhatex and me.   Sounds about right.  This is my first faro, I was pretty excited for this.  Pours a hazy amber orange with a white head that disappears quick.  The nose is sour with apples, oak, and must like a dusty attic that has oak floors, with apples starting to rot.  So tart.  Those notes apples, oranges, oak, musty, earthy, and surprisingly sugarry.  A little acidic but not so.  Interesting beer.
Poured amber with white head. Aroma of fruit. Good sour fruit flavor. Not much to this.

Aroma:Very good fruity aroma...
Appearance:Clear amber,light head..
Flavor:fruity berries,sour flavor......

37.5 cl bottle.  Clear rusty yellow with waves of tiny streaming bubbles that maintain a slim white head.  Soft peach sweetness gives way to floral vinegar.  Taste is more dilute than other lambics ive had but certainly doesnt diminish the appeal.  Creamy lemon pith with subdued champagne carb.  Earthy plum pits and sour apricot.  Dry bready finish with hints of pepper and clover honey.  Im quite surprised this was so good.  Style 70/71!

Dark amber hue, with a beige big head, leaving laces, sweet sugary wheaty malt nose with some barnyard and musty accents, with a stewed apple fruity note, some wet oakiness, candy sugar, and a tart aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a wild yeast mustiness, some toasted caramelized malts, with some sweet and tart notes, with a hint of fruity pruney accent, with a  wet woody, oaky character, some candy sugar, leading towards a sweet malty, tart and acidic finish. My kind of beer!

One of the many, "Drewbeerme is back and is a badass for sharing so many awesome Belgium beers" tasting with Holdenn and me.  Bottle.  Hazy dark orange-brown, with off-white/beige head.  Sour aroma, lemon, dusty/earthy.  Green/red apple flavor, slight lemon, not very acidic, orange (that tastes like its about to go bad), sweet, dry winey, earthy.  Thin, watery not unappropiate, no carb.  Not too exciting but not bad none the less.

375ml bottle. pours auburn with white head. nose is sweet and sorta musty. flavor of green apples and sorta musty. pretty hard to rate this actually, mouth feel is pretty watery. interesting and better than i thought it would be. refreshing and pretty sweet.

375ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Lambic days 2007)
Pumpkin orange, light loose head. Slightly sour, slightly sweet but very malty aroma. Slightly buttery slightly woody malt taste. Very dry but very drinkable.
Brown of color with a beige head. An aroma of sour sugar, notes of sweets and sour. A flavor of sweets, caramel, nuts and sour notes.

Date: 03/12/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Tasting

hazy dark amber, wispy beige head, aroma is both sweet and tart with a musty character, lots of tart flavor that kicks your salvatory glands into high gear, nice fruity character in the middle, the tartness comes back for a long tart finish

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 6/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 11/20
Rating: 2.9/5.0Drinkability: 6/10
Score: *4

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Bottle: Poured a light reddish/brown color lambic with a big foamy off-white head with limited retention. Aroma is quite funky with limited tartness and acidity which was a bit disappointing. Taste was similar to the gueuze but as if the tartness and acidity had been removed and replace with light sugary notes. Body was a bit too light with some good carbonation. I find it always interesting too try those traditional examples but this one really miss the mark.

Re-rate January 2008: Poured a light reddish color faro with a sizeable foamy head with good retention. Aroma of candi sugar with some light green apple and some melon. Taste is a lot more enjoyable then when I had previously tasted this beer. Probably one of the best Faro Ive had the chance to try recently.

0.375 l bottle. Dark  amber color with peige head. Sweet and sour aroma with weird piney and resiny notes reminescent of tequila. More sweet than acidic flavor with some sugary notes. Also vinous and resiny notes in the flavor. Fairly straightforward but pleasant. At Pikkulintu in Helsinki there was a blond and totally different tasting version of this beer!

Bottle from Boutip consumed last night. Thanks Phil!  My first faro experience. After letting it warm for 35 mins or so, I popped this baby and poured it into my 3Fonteinen tumbler. Lots of carbonation, I dont know why but I was surprised by this. Nose was sort of like what I expected, a mix of sweet and sour, heavy on the malts with some notes of apple cider vinegar and olives.  Pour was rich dark amber brown with a fizzy white head that leaves a small ring of beige lacing. Flavor is rich and the body is thick--much thicker than any lambic Iv ever had. Might even call it bready. More green (sour) apples, brown sugar, vinegar, and wood.  This had a funky balance, normally when I look at the flavors I have listed this sounds like a beer I would love, but the consistency was just kind of fluttered and everything didnt meld as well as I would have liked. This was pretty good and I actually enjoyed some of the flavors at times,  but when I got to the last few sips I just couldnt bring myself to finish it. Nonetheless, I cant wait to try some more.

Bottle @ Pikkulintu, Helsinki. Half-hazy honey colour, extreme beige head. Aroma of cloudberry, apple and even some nuts. Taste extremely thick, with a bite of green apple that will eventually kill you :)

(Bottled) Slightly hazy darkish amber with a medium, tanned head. Slightly tart and sweet aroma with some dried fruitiness and hints of vomit. Tart, but sweet-malty flavor with vinous fruitiness and a sweet, lightly bitter and astringent finish. Slightly sweet and sticky, medium-bodied palate with a bit fizzy carbonation. A balanced, but not very complex or interesting faro. I still wish the sugar was supplied in a separate bag with the beer, so you could choose whether to pour it in or not :)

Bottle, 5%. Quite sweet, slightly vinous and mouldy aroma. Seemingly clear chestnut colour. Very small head, low carbonation. The flavour is slightly sour and quite vinous, like port the way I do not like it. Not very sweet. OK for a faro (which I have trouble enjoying).

Small quickly disappearing head. Brown-redish color. Good carbonation. Aroma is balance between sweet and sour. Brown sugar taste is rather dominant. Also some fruits. Again nice balance between sour- and sweetness.

On tap at t Warm Water, Brussels. Maybe it should be listed separately from the bottled version since it seems to be of quite a different calibre. Mahogny colour without the slightest sign of any foam. Sweet raisins aroma, reminding me of white port. Complex sweet flavours, predominantly raisins, vanilla, candy sugar and oak. More woodiness towards the drier finish. Light to medium body. One of the best faros around?

Small beige head quickly reduced to a thin layer. Misty reddish amber colored body. Nice acidulous dry fruitiness to the  nose. Taste is acidic and tart with some brown sugar-sweetness to mellow the flavors. Notes of grapefruit, unripe red berries and vinegar. Light sweet and acidic finish. Refreshing.

Appearance: Low fill, and a rubber cork. Distinct red brown colour with a big fluffy Belgian style head which disappears quickly.
Aroma: Honey, clover, cloves (spicy) Sweet and sour aroma, pineapple, hay and pears.
