375 ml bottle
Rating #500Thanks to hopdog for sending this in a recent trade.  Ive been looking for something special and this seems to be appropriate.  Since it is possibly the hardest style to find, I figured I would save it for a special occasion.  Having sampled it I would love to try a fresh faro to see how they compare.  Despite not having very many expectations it was still a bit of a letdown for a rare style.
Aroma / Appearance - The deep brown body had almost no carbonation or head instead swirling around the glass easily.  A sweet fruity smell permeated the space above the glass with raspberry and blueberries.  There was a trace amount of funkiness but nothing like what you get from other lambics.
Flavor / Palate - The taste of semisweet lemons is soon followed by tart raspberries.  It reminds me alot of Lipton iced tea mixed with nutrasweet or powdered sugar.  The finish is dry and sour but not harsh.  This is definitely one of the most unique beers I have tried.  While it is sippable and easy to drink Im not sure I would want more than a single bottle at once.
yellow body with a white head.some lacing on the glass as the head rests.aroma of funk,vinegar,and feet.flavor is vinegar apple cider,and sour funk.nice balance of sweet and sour.
Body is gold, thin white head.  Aroma is honey, yeast, tartness, with light tea/caramel.  Taste is lightly sweet, light lemon tartness to it.

By far the best of the 4 faros Ive had; Bottle from Papsoe; Nose of funk and horseblanket; Orange-gold with a small offwhite head; Flavor of tart apple, very light, but well balanced sweetness, a little caramel, with a tart finish; unlike the other faros Ive had well balanced and closer to a guezue in flavor, not so sweet!
bottle. amber golden color. medium head. sweet aroma and taste. carpy on tounge and the sweet is sugar and candy.
Bottled. Dark rubyish brown colour, mediumsized beige head. Aroma is caramel and a lot of sourness. Flavour is the same with some malty and fruity hints. Also slight metallicness noted.

Bottle 37,5 cl. (Yesterday @ KBW) Deep orange/amber color with a small white head. Aroma was little caramel, and lambic like, some sweetness. Medium body. Taste malty, gueuze like, light sweet - sourness. Good balance.

Bottle in Mechalen, north? wee cafe where we had a drinkl while we realised we had got off at the wrong station. Aroma is spitsery tart fruit, hints of lambic funk but sweetness getting in the way. Taste is a bit bloody, caramel malts stop the gueuze from getting through.

Bottle (From RBF07). Suprisingly deep colour. Fruity toffeish sugars mixed with more lambic like aromas. The sourness from the lambic is present but is mostly overwhelmed by the slightly artificial sweetness which doesnt always combine well with the sourness - producing an almost sweet smell of sick. Better than the lindemann faro I tried.

Bottle. 37.5 cl. Unclear orange color with a average fizzy good lacing mostly lasting off-white head. Aroma is light toffee / caramel, berry sweet and sour. Initial flavor is moderate sweet and finish flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter with a average duration. Body is light to medium, texture is watery to oily, carbonation is soft.

Bottle picked up from Beers of Europe at the end of April. Pours a copper colour with very good clarity, with a small white head. Aroma is a bit rustic and earthy. Taste is very pleasant sweet dark sugars compete with a nice subdued tangy sourness that sits just below, some citrusy fruits hang in there just to complete this fine flavoured beer.
Bottle. High white and flufy but lasting head. Hazy copper body. Weak fruity aroma of grape fruit plus barley malt. Sugary and sweet flavor of grape fruit but without aný sharp edges.

Bottle sampled on 3/12/07: Pours a clear bright copper bronze with a thin ring of spotty-lacing off-white head.  Sweet toasty caramel sugar aroma has a touch of sweatiness and some fruity esters.  Body starts slightly sweet with lots of fruity tartness and a drier, earthy, crisp finish.  A decent, and interesting brew.

375 ml bottle, via Papsoe.  Bottle 4 of a 4 bottle Faro tasting.  Pours a slightly hazy brown body under a fizzy off-white head that left some sticky lacing.  Aroma is pretty subdued, some light earthy funk, light fruitiness, a little candi/brown sugar, and some soft maltiness.  The most Gueuze like Faro of the 5 Ive had, with a fairly minimal sugar presence.  The sugar that is there tastes alot more raw than the others as opposed to the more refined sugar taste of the others.  The sugar just takes that acetic sour bite away that some folks find offensive about Gueuze instead of completely covering it up.  Alot more crisp and bitey than the other 4 as well on the finish.  Mouthfeel is quite nice, lively fine carboination with minimal stickiness on the finish.  A slight acetic bite late in the finish.  Clearly the best of the bottled Faros available, and easily the most drinkable.  The only one of the bunch of 5 that Id ever buy again.

Thanks to hopdog for breaking out this bottle. Stamped 01 04 on the cork...
Appears a transparent light amber with a small, light tan head the quickly fades away. Nary a bit of lacing is left around the glass. Tiny amounts of CO2 rise to the top.
Smell is of butter cream, caramel, brown sugar, light funk, oxidation, and mild cork.
Taste is sugary up front, rubbery, fresh plastic bags out of the box(if that makes sense), and light brown sugar.
Mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly tannic of wood, a bit of a "yuck" factor with the plastic notes and junky garbage outweighing the intriguing wild yeast notes that are present.
This is a weird style and Ive got nothing to really compare it against. Im going by my overall impressions of this brew.
Bottle: Starts sour than will change lightly to sweet. Hints of citrus, caramel that makes a well balance.

Bottle. Cork stamped 01 04 (or at least thats the consensus we came up with as it was hard to read!). Poured a deep orange/amber color with a small sized off white head. Looking at my notes, the first thing I wrote down about the aroma was Huh?. After some time, I was able to pickout plastic, some oxidation, caramel, and butterscotch. Tastes were sugary, with caramel, and citrus. My first Faro, and I can say it was definitely different.

Poured a red amber color with a small, off white head that left light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of butterscotch, nuts, caramel, wood, and light oxidation.  Taste of brown sugar, with more caramel, nuts, light wood, with citrus, and a tart, bretty finish.

Bottle: Sourly aroma of citrus, vinegar and sourish fruits. Ruby red color, small off-white head. Light caramelic sugar notes but largely quite sourly flavor with light notes of cider, vinegar and citrus. Quite astringent finish. Quite nice candy note but all in all not overwhelming.

Poured a mostly clear amber color with a small off-white head.  the aroma was a mix of sweet malt and tartness.  Notes of sweaty feet and apples.  The flavor was tart and sweet.  Tart red apples.  The finish was clean, dry and acidic.  Medium bodied with a soft mouthfeel.

Thanks to the Atlanta crew for sharing.  The only style I hadnt already had!!!  Clear amber, very thin light tan head.  Nose is sweet caramel, funky, cheese.  Flavor is lemon, caramel, grape, orange.  Acidic but sweet finish, some lemonhead notes.  Very bright fruit.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from rake. Reddish amber with a very thin white head. Nose of red wine, vinegar and brown sugar. Tart yeasty grapefruit taste with a sweet caramel finish and fine carbonation. All the attributes of a nice gueuze with a sweet edge. Mmmmm....

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2008 On tap @ Zythos. Amber color, aroma of dry, sour fruits. Coppery, cidery flavor with the musty-dusty finish of a drink thats been open on your nightstand for a few days. And excellent. Not an especially sweet faro, as the sugar mellows the sourness into a balanced, refreshing drink. RE-RATED after tasting at Bier Circus, where it was darker and sweeter than I remember.
Bottle. Pours a pale red with a fizzy head that completely disappears. Mildly fruity aroma. Lightly fizzy mouthfeel as well. An initial sweetness that turns slightly sour.

Bottle. Head was average fizzy and white which mostly diminished. Body was slightly cloudy like with an amber reddish colour. Aroma was quit a surprise with a strange combination of sweat, horse blanket, barnyard, leather, earth, mould and other notes of light flowers and some grapefruit, vinegar and apple. Mouthfeel wasnt unpleasant as you might thing after that description. Light sour fruit with light notes of sweetness blending in. Medium bodied with a soft carbonation and a slightly acidic finish. Strange experience, but not entirely unpleasant.

Bottle - Hazy amber body with a creamy white head leaving some lacing; Medium sized nose with aromas that doesnt seem all settled, lots of cane sugar, lots of apple and lots of sharp warm vinegar; Perfect a little sharp carbonation in body, soft texture, quite full and a little bitter with both lactic and fruits acids behind; Medium long finish that seems a bit hoppy bitter dry and actually has hop aromas, not a lot of acid and it seems a bit dusty. Nothing wrong with Faro this one just doesnt do the job well.

(37.5 cl bottle at Delirium Café, Göteborg) Dark redish brown color, big lasting tan head. Sour lactic type scent, like soured milk left out in room temperature. Sour and strangely bitter taste. Sour aftertaste with some mouthpuckering bitterness, but not from hops more from chewing on grape peels.
Sampled with family after Christmas dinner. Got the bottle from janka in a trade at the GABF. Hazy, amber color. Burnt sugar aroma. sweet, with a tart flavor that persists throught the finish.

Bottle from Ölbuttiken, Copenhagen. This is my first Lambic Faro and I was expecting a sugary sweet beer with mild sourness. In reality this is actually very pleasantly balanced, with restrained sweetness and a medium tart finish wrapped up in a wonderfully smooth mouthfeel.
Poured a hazy hazelnut with a frothy white head into a nucleated glass, so the head stayed until the bitter end. Nice sticky lacing.
Smell of apple, grapefruit and wet rope, with a splash of vinegar and  a dollop of vanilla. Taste is citrus sharp up front, a burst of apples in the middle and a tasteful sour finish. The nice chap at Ölbuttiken said this was a good entry point for those unfamiliar with lambics  and I think hes right.
Bottle. Small head with short duration. Lively carbonation. Color is amber. Aroma and taste is a bit sour and bitter.

Slight cloudy orange amber with small white head (not very long lasting). Aroma is sweet and sour, it has fine touches of honey, wood, cakes, sour fruits and apples. Taste is very nice, apples, cane sugar, sweet bread, honey and some woody tanines with a faint bitterness in the finale. 8/3/7/3/15
Aroma is malty, slightly woody and fruity. Hazy, brown coloured with a lasting, brownish medium head. Taste is sweet, just a bit tart, fruity and malty. Medium body.

(bottle, shared by pivnizub) Slightly hazy, golden coloured effervescent hue with a nice and stable yellowish foamy head. Moderately sweet and slightly tart fruity and sugary aroma. Light bodied, fairly aromatic fruity (apple) and slightly sweet taste; slim and moderately tart finish (05.10.06).
Bottle, 37,5 cl. Nice amber with a firm head. Fine citrus smell. Refreshing, sour, but in a pleasant way. Some light fruit, cider-like.
Bottle. Medium sourness stays even throughout. Pretty interesting and not as sweet as youd think it might be, although fair amount of caramel about. Notes of orange peel too.

(Bottle 37,5 cl) Pours a slightly hazy amber golden with a creamy, beige head. Odd, tart aroma - sweaty Brettomyces - and then some notes of burned caramel. Medium body with sweetnsour accents with a rather astringent tartness ending up as the winner. Very complex and rather interesting. 081006

Bottle: Hazy, lively carbonation, amber coloured, big firm head; caramelly, sugary, slightly fruity (apples) aroma with a light sourness; light sweetish-sourish flavour, light bodied; an illusion of tartness in the sweetish-fruity finish. O.K., like a heavily diluted "Gueuze" for the summer.............
Bottle. Clear dark amber coloured. Honey and apricots - brown sugar. A bit dry finish - feels a bit oily in the mouth. Way way too sweet.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm, labeled "Sparkling") Colour is pale mahogany, with a disappearing white head. Nose is bitter-sweet with notes of dried fruit and brown sugar. The same goes for the taste: the harsh sourness battling with brown sugar sweetness, hints of dried fruit and notes of barnyard. Rather complex, but a bit unbalanced. I definitely prefer the straightforward harsh sourness of their lambic.
Bottle at Cambrinus Rest. Brugges 25/05/06. Apricot/Honey colour body, off-white head. Residual sugar at the back of the palate, moderate carbonation, light to medium body, oily, no head retention.
toffee colored, some head.  light fruit and sweetness aroma.  sour and fruity taste.  super flat finish.  pretty dry.  a crazy beer.
375ml bottle from The Rake.  Toffee apple aroma.  Gorgeous toffee colour.  Not as sweet as you would expect.  Rather yummy in fact with a sourish finish.  Extremely moreish.
I hate lambics of all sorts.  Thats why this was my second to last style to drink.  This one wasnt that bad because it had all that sugar to mask the awful sour flavor.

375ml bottle at the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/sweden/s target=blank>Akkurat in Stockholm, Sweden.  Very deep murky golden-amber in colour.  Medium sized off-white coloured head, lots of lacing.  The aroma is quite sweet, lots of brown sugar and gingerbread, some herbal hops, earthy.  The flavour is sweet at first, lemon citrus juice, gingerbread, brown sugar, some caramel.  Slightly sticky mouthfeel, light body, light carbonation.  Finishes sweet, with some very light herbal bitterness.  This is a bizarre style but so far I am liking what I have tried.

On tap into gueuze glass, Delirium Tremens, Brussels.  Translucent brown sugar in its own tumbler; tan head keeps a thin cover on the beer for a long time.  Sudsy lace is uniform and frothy, racing deep and slow in bubbly rivulets beneath the surface.  Apricot and sawdust on the nose with an accent of charred maize (like Indian corn that sat on a grill for too long).  Nice round acid character provides a tart sourness like apples in the middle, all surrounded by soft cobweb yeast.  Finishes kind of like a German lager at the start when the hops peek through, then settles into more sourness and a bit of prickly bitterness.  Sweetness all the way through keeps this from ever being dry, and a solidly medium body with subdued carbonation keeps it from quintessential summer beer status (not that I would need one sitting at a table outside in Brussels today, since Im sure its below 50 degrees right now); that being said, very refreshing.  As the beer warms, the grilled corn emerges sometimes from underneath the blanket of sour apple flavor.  Enjoyable as my first Belgian beer in Belgium.
Amber and slightly hazy with a large tan head. Aroma had diacetyl and a cidery sweetness. Taste was tart at first but passed pleasantly through sweet apple to a sharp grapefruit finish. Excellent.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with a thick pretty fast disappearing tan head. Sweet and slightly acid aroma. Sweet flavor with some nice sourness. Finsih is sweet and a bit sour. A nice faro.

375cc bottle gained in trade many moons ago from Jeppe.  Pours out a clear, toasted brown color with a really weird head which reminds me of a clingy, retentive soda pop head.  Spotty lacing is left behind.  Modest lactic acid nose with a healthy dose of sugar thrown in, fairly appealing.  First taste gives you just a touch of sour/tart and then some moderate sweetness moves in to balance things out fairly well.  Medium bodied, decently carbonated.  Best of the few Faro styled beers that I have tried.

Bottle - corked and caged. Clear amber with a small tan head. Nose is fruity and sweet with a slight sourness to it. Taste coems through mainly sweet with some sugary notes but has a slightly sour fruitiness to it along with green apple notes and light barnyard. Body is light and mildly carbonated. Light acidity as well. Finishes sweet and lightly soured with mild fruit coming through as well as some sugary notes.

(Bottle.  03/2006)  Clear, amber.  Fast-disipating, fizzy white head.  Nose of diacetyl (strong butterscotch), autolysis (rotting meat), and oxidation (cardboard).  No real acetic notes which makes the aroma quite unappealing for a lambic product.  Butterscotch mixed with sweet caramel on the mouth.  Overly sweet and way, way too buttery ... oily palate.

Pours with a slightly hazy golden body topped by a medium thick, white head with some lacing.  Its sweet with a touch of sourness and a little bitterness and some underlying horseblanket.  Light to medium bodied, smooth and a touch dry.

(375ml bottle) Lightly hazed copper body with medium beige head.  Aroma is mild sweet, vinegar, some horseblanket.  Taste is mild sweet, vinegar, some fruity.  Caramel in the finish, with light brown sugar.  Light-medium body with no acidity.  My first Faro, not nearly as sweet as I had feared.

Murky amber with a frothy off-white head. Decent lace. Aroma is musty sweet. Cardboardy oxiadation also present. Caramel throughoiyut but prounounced in the finsih. Soft body. Ok, I guess, for what it is. Leagues better than the othe Faro I have had, Chapeau.

Foxy-amber, totally clear beer with slim off-white head. Rotting nose, caramel, rotting meat, wood (also...), cardboard. Slight sourish edge around wood, cardboard, and quite some caramel(syrup) sweetness. Not really cloying, but still... Slick, but not oversyrupy MF. Very ho-hum faro, can do much better; the nose is revolting.

Bottled.  Wow - wierd even by Faro standards.  A reddy brown malt vinegar coloured beer with no head.  The aroma is a real mixture:  deep fruits, caramel, wood soaked in vinegar and sweaty feet.  The taste is more sour than expected; similar in some ways to a Flemish Red with that woody oaky feel, and old red fruit, but there is the sugariness dwelling deep down.  A schizophrenic drink in that some mouthfuls are sublime but others are almost unpleasant.  As acquired a taste as any beer Ive had and one I would willingly redrink just to see how much I really did like it.

Light hazy amber color. Small white head. Smell is like apple cider. Green musty apple accents with nice honeyed tones. Taste is soft and refreshing. It has a nice crisp, a good soury sharpness and a great balance. A great summer drink.

Bottled. Amber body, beige mostly lasting head. Good lacing. In the aroma: white grape, fermented grape, mint. The background scent is sweet and woody, sugars come through. Dry body. Hoppy bitterness in the flavor: does not taste like a classic faro. Tee leaf in the aftertaste. If Lindemans Faro raises you from the dead in a hot, sultry afternoon  this one is for a hot evening on a terrace, on a lake, in the mountains, wherever close to the nature
Bottled. Aroma is very fruity, mainly white grapes. Alsmost clear, amber color, beige head, good lace. Sweet & sour, quite bitter for a faro, fruity, tealeaves. Light sticky and a dry bitter finish.

Bottle at RBESG grand tasting, August 2005. Its difficult to conceive that Id ever go as far as saying I disliked a Girardin lambic, but, as with all Faros, I find myself thinking, whats the point? Make a world class lambic, with all the cheesy, farmyardy, tart qualities you expect. Then dump a load a sugar in to make it more palatable to people that dont like what makes lambic great. Suppose you could say the same about sweet ciders though. Its testament to the beer that this treatment doesnt ruin it entirely.

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2007 Bottle from Bierkonig.  Copper colored, good sized, off white head.   Aroma of apples and melons(mostly melon), sweet.  Does taste a little woody.  Flavor is sort of like sweet and sour pork(with out the meat).  Tame by lambic standards and very fresh tasting.

Bottled with a plastic cork, Girardin goes modern...
Amber color. Not very much of an aroma. A vague woody caramelly touch. Sweet flavor, woody with lemon. Caramelly, dusty. A bit of nutty bitterness. Some sherry character. Likeable, but not my favorite from Girardin.
pretty caramel color with a fat yellow white head. raspberry nose like a raspberry muffin. seedless grape taste. tart syrupy notes like raspberry jam. very fruity flavor. yummy.

(Bottle, courtesy of Lumpy & Kevin)  Pours a cloudy amber-brown body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of wild raspberries and cider. Mildly tart flavor with a dry finish.  Mellow, but refreshing lambic.

I had the bottom pour from the bottle, but there wasnt much there.  It kept a good head, off-white on a clear bronze appearance.  Fruity aroma, retaining some sour barnyard but without the sour dimension.  In the flavor the sweet side is there in healthy proportion and it keeps some raspberry, strawberry, and cherry hints.  Not flat but not lively either.  Im so happy to have tried this--thanks Lumpy and Kevin for acquiring it.

Iced tea body with a thick film of bubbles. Nose-sweet like berries. Taste-some mild geuze like flavors with an overwhelming sweetness. Very, very light funk with some tartness. Tastes like a good mild geuze that somebody dumped alot of Sweet-N-Low into.
Clear pretty brown. Head was good and firm. Big fizziness. Tarter then any other Faro that I have had. I would normally love this style.

37.5 cL bottle courtesy of sk8viking.  Gotta love the plastic cork!  Rather deep sparkling golden pour with 1/2" of dense off-white head.  Aroma picked up some caramel, light horse blankets, lime, and had an underlying sweetness... but just wasnt that strong.  Excellent mouthfeel with just the right amount of carbonation.  Finish was of limes coated in sugar (odd sweet/tart sensation)... yet was remarkably refreshing.  Body of the flavor was carried by the sweetness and light orange peel.  Quite an intriguing and refreshing brew.

Bottle. Faros are always strange ones for me. Sweetish, tart candy sugar character, mixed with the lambic sourness. I liked this one OK,  but im really not sure about the style. I didnt realise it had a plastic cork!?!

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2005 A Mes rate: 
Oh the excitement! 37.5cl bottle at Delirium Cafe. Very very good stuff indeed. A tad darker than other faros. Much closer to a straight forward lambic than a faro in my experience. Not over the top sweet as some faros can be. Huge rocky head that left chunky almost fungal lace. Body is sheer genius. Its one of those that I feel like I could swill round my mouth all day.  Thoroughly enjoyed it right down to the very last drop. Would love to try this from a pump. Big big shame about the plastic cork though.
9/17/05 I admit to being a little bit on my way when I first rated this. After my second bottle i bought the numbers down just a little for the artificial sweetness, which is quite clear. Still very good stuff though.

Bottled - I was quite amazed that I saw a bottled version of Girardins faro, because untill recent you only could by it in a keg of 10 liters.  The beer itself has a very clear, deep amber body and a light brown, frothy head which diminishes mostly.  A spare lace.  The aroma has some hops (lightly citric) and malts in it.  Lightly bitter, moderately sweet initial flavour and a lightly bitter, lightly sour finish.  (This change of flavours from sweet-bitter to sour-bitter is remarkable.)  Their lambic is also omnipresent in the flavour.  This is a quite weird faro.

Bottle, RBESG 2005, Grand Tasting. My first faro. Clear brown colour, caramel and barnyard in the aroma. Flavour is sour and sweet, hints of Norwegian "Flux Soda" soft drink. Hints of dark crab meat(!) too.

Bottle at RBESG Grand Tasting 05. Fairly plain. Slightly bolognese sauce flavour. Not overly sour or fresh - if anything there was a kind of jammy sourness.Reasonable only, especially as I was expecting a world beating example of the style here.

(on bottle at RBESG 2005)Rusty coloured, white head, not much tnough. A flat mouthfeel and a sour-sweet taste of kandis and bramble. Not a kicker, but an ok, quiet pour for a lazy afternoon, not a grand tasting.
Bottle. Youghurt-like sourness. Very sweet on the palate and again with the feeling of drinking youghurt. A waste of good lambic.

Bottled @RBESG05
Clear copper brown, small white head. Extremely sour nose. Soft palate. Sourness mixed with candy sugar. Sourish aftertaste, not too sweet faro.

nice faro, not really sweet thought. woody, fruity aroma. taste: a bit acidity, bit sweet, woody, fruity. finish is long with lots of caramel and a little fruitiness. indeed a pity they used artificial sweetener.

(Bottle at Belgian Belly, Manchester).  It was avery hot day and this was really refreshing, but..... is that artificial sweetener I taste?  I mean, Girardin are one of the best Lambic brewers... surely they could have gone for REAL sugar instead of caramel and acesulfame-K?  Let down by the crap additives, but still nice-enough but, as has been said, nowhere near the classic 3-fonteinen.

A pretty good faro, as faros go.  It was lightly sweetened and helped the lambic sourness go down more easily.  Since Ive had so few faros, Im only guessing that this is a better-than-average one since its a Girardin.  Still lightly sour and cloudy with lots of flavor.  Very enjoyable and more my style than straight lambics.  The bartender at Copenhagens Plan B scoffed when I ordered it.  Whatever, dude.

Bottled.
Clear orange coloured with a lasting white head.
Acidic aroma with notes of fruits.
Very carbonated.
Acidic flavour with woody notes.
Very refreshing.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2006 375 ml corked bottle from Ølbutikken. After trying Lindemanns Faro some years ago I have avoided beers of this style. 
Unusually dark for a lambic style brew (could be the sweetener). Excellent head, which lasts until the last sip. The aroma is slightly tart - more citric than really vinegarlike. Refreshing flavor which is well balanced - not being really sour or sweet - just thirst quenching. Ends with long smooth caramel. Champagne like carbonation, without feeling watery.
Copper color. Very strange, very cheesy example (soft, not ammonia), some vinegar aroma. Some sweetness.

Draught, Brussels, Warm Water, May 2005.

Body is hazy medium brown.

Aroma is lightly malty (caramel), with notes of candy sugar and sherry.

Flavor is heavily sweet, moderately acidic.
Finish is moderately sweet, moderately acidic.

Medium body, watery texture, soft carbonation.

Once youve had Armand Debelders faro, its hard to take anyone elses seriously.  This is no exception...a sugary sweet glass of banality.

Bottled 37,5 cl, In de Wildeman, Amsterdam. Copper coloured, small head. Obvious lambic-character in aroma, quite ok. Flavour however is cloyingly sweet, predominantly caramel. After a few sips the flavour really gets annoying. No match for the other girardin brews.

Bottle, In de Wildeman, Amsterdam. Clear amber color, short off-white head. Aroma of sweet candysugar, some horseblanket, caramel. Taste is sweet like a faro, but too sweet, bit more spicy and caramel malty. Im not a fan of Faro, and i think ill never gonna be...
Amber, almost copper in colour. Mild caramel aroma, with decent fruity notes in the background. Sweet sugar balanced with woody fruity flavours. Nice stuff.
Deep golden colour with a small white head. Sour, light fruity aroma with sugar notes. Sweet and yeasty flavor in a nice balanced beer.
Keg @ Akkurat, Stockholm. Labeled Girardin "Sparkling" Faro. 10 May 2005Bronze coloured. Caramellised sugar in both aroma and taste. Oak character in the background.
Golden, white lasting head. Quite weak sour flavor. Sweet, sour flavor, some yeast. Feels a little artificial...

Draught at Warm Water, Brussels. Brown, rather clear - flat with no head. Aroma is lambicy and sour. Flavour is nice and is typical based on my previous faro tastingsm sweet and slightly tart with a ltitle sourness. Well balanced compared to others, not oversweet and not unpleasently sickly like others.
Copenhagen beer marathon 2004, red-brown color, medium grassy herbal aroma, sweet sour taste, full body, dry sweet sour finish.

Bag-in-a-box At Copenhagen Beermarathon 2004: Chestnut brown with no head at all. Aroma is mostly kandis and vinaigre, Taste is very well balanced between the sourness of the lambic, and the sweetness of the sugar. Without a doubt the best Faro i ever had
Sampled from a bag.in-box cask. Dark copper body. Sweetish aroma, with a nice sour undertone. Fruity flavor, swwet and sour. Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2005 Clear chestnut, tanned creamy head.
Fruity, wooden and leathery aroma.
Wooden and leathery tastenotes, seweet brown sugar.
not fizzy at all - sparkly and round mouthfeel. dry finish.
Wooden aftetaste.

UPDATED: JUN 24, 2009 Amber-brown with a thick, bumpy head.  Sugary nose has hints of toffee.  Sweet and sour palate, the former being very caramel/toffee sweet and the latter being a clean lactic tartness.  Theres a bit of lemonyness in there as well.  The result is a fairly aggressive faro - probably the least faro-like faro Ive had.

Light sweet nose, herbal, grassy, saccharin. Cola brown clear with no head. Medium watery body with low carb. Starts sweet chalky, with light lactic notes. Very saccharin finish and after. For me, not enjoyable. Vinegar.

Deep reddish brown coloured. Aroma of caraamel and acidic vinegar. Well balanced flavour with sugary sweetness and lambic sourness and tartness. This is very tasty. However, I still think that adding stuff to one of the most fantastic and complex brews of the world, Girardin Lambic, is a crime.

Sampled from a Jolly Cola bottle?
Well, it is a nice Faro. I didnt find it that sweet actually, but it was pretty sour and a bit apricot maybe. I liked it, a nice substitution to water.

Sampled from a 10 litre cardboard cask.Deep copper colored beer with no head. Very delicious aroma with a nice balanced sourness and tones of grapefruit and wood. Flavor has a slight sweetness at first, but then the sourness hits in. Dry and woody with grapefruit notes. Not as sweet as expectet and as most other Faros! Thanks Jacob Lövenlund for sharing!

Deep amber light chestnut color with little or no head. The taste is a complex sourness almost like sweet lemon og dry grape. Light notes of spices and of course pleasantly balanced with the brown sugar.

10 L Cardboard box: Clear dark amber coloured. No head. Sweet and fruity aroma. Has a light sourness in the background. Flavour is a good mix of sweet fruityness and some sourness. Maybe a little too much sweetness. Ends acidic and dry with some great grapenotes. Thanks Jacob for sharing.

A deep red beer with no head. The aroma is sweet with notes of sugar on a sour background but also hints of wood. The flavor is dominated by grapefruit and is sweet on a sour background with notes of wood lending it a dryness and hints of brown sugar. The sourness is not that accentuated, but yet it draws some mouthwater. It ends on a note of grapefruit.
(sampled from a "Bag in box" at Akkurat, Stockholm, Sweden)Amber, no head. Sweet, fruity and a bit unclean aroma. Sweet and vinous flavour. Some hard to define fruitiness. Some sour notes in finish.

Sampled draught (bag-in-box) at Akkurat, Stockholm.
Reddish amber, clear no head. Apple aroma. Sweet and still, fruity and clean. Pleasant and caramelly up front, but with artificial saccaharine liek finish. Not up to par with the rest of the Girardins
